description: Niger closed the airports of Niamey and Zinder for a period of two week from March 19 onward and the closure of all land borders. International flights into Niger's international airports resumed on August 1, 2020. Land borders in Niger have remained closed, however, passengers with special permission and merchandise are allowed. UPDATE: The original policy was that the airports in Niamey and Zinder were closed for a period of two weeks onward from March 19 and all land borders were also closed. On August 1, 2020 commercial international flights into all of Niger's international airports resumed. However, land borders are still closed, except for people with special permission or those carrying merchandise.

description: On the 21st March 2020, the governor of the Nigerian state of Akwa Ibom "appealed for utmost caution and deep sense of rationality, especially from the media, in the manner of reportage of the global pandemic, adding that there is no redeeming value in causing panic in the State". He assured the public that "the rumours and false information going around on social media are completely false…there is no confirmed case of COVID-19 disease in Akwa Ibom State.”

description: Nasarawa State,Nigeria, cautioned residents against spreading fake news on coronavirus that could cause panic in the state on March 25 an stated: “The public should rely only on information from government and experts on COVID-19 and not allow themselves to be misled by some unpatriotic elements whose aim is to cause confusion,”.

description: Osun state, Nigeria, announced April 2 that the governor has signed the Osun Infectious Diseases (Emergency Prevention) Regulations 2020. Under the law transmission or dissemination of false information regarding Covid-19 is an offense and anybody who violates the law will be sentenced to six-month imprisonment or an option of fine upon conviction.

description: On June 16th, 2020, Nigeria conducted training of health reporters and journalists on factual reporting on COVID-19 in Kano State. The primary goal was to prevent the spread of fake news surrounding COVID-19 and its status in the country. The non-governmental organization "Breakthrough Action-Nigeria" as well as the Federal Ministry of Health conducted the training in order to help reporters and journalists identify scams, fabricated information, and conspiracy theories, among other issues, before proliferating information and sources.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Nigeria, june 26 - a recent collaboration of the Borno State Government with the World Health Organisation to launch a campaign tagged ‘COVID-19 Heroes Campaign’ launched on May 29 in Borno State.The deputy governor noted that the campaign was aimed at demystifying COVID-19 and putting a stop to the stigmatisation of those affected by the pandemic, adding that sufferers of the disease should be celebrated by all rather than stigmatised.

description: Osun state, Nigeria, has a one-day training program on Covid-19 reporting for selected radio reporters on July 1. The programme is organized by the Ministry of Information and Civic Orientation in collaboration with the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund(UNICEF).

description: The Anambra State Government of Nigeria announced on July 13, 2020 that they were aware of a group of criminals parading in fake Covid-19 Task Force uniforms. These criminals had been arresting people and extorting huge sums of money from them while posturing as working for the government of Anambra State. The government indicated that the only agencies authorized to enforce the Anambra State Covid-19 Law are the members of OCHA Brigade and ATMA. Additionally, the government warned these fake operators that the Anambra State Police Command has been directed to search for, arrest and prosecute anybody masquerading as a Covid-19 Task Force operator.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
The Honourable Minister of Health, Dr. Osagie Ehanire has called for caution amid declining cases of COVID-19 in the country as he said this could be attributed to the fact that we are yet to perfect our act in the containment of the virus. Dr. Ehanire gave this caution during the Presidential Task Force (PTF) on COVID-19 Press Briefing in Abuja on Monday, 30th August, 2020.

In his words, “We are beginning to see a situation where the number of those treated and discharged exceeds the number of positive cases detected. While these figures may seem reassuring, they may be deceptive, and we cannot assume that the curve is flattening, since we are yet to perfect due diligence on our side.”
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
14 September 2020 | Abuja – Update on the Nigeria International Travel Portal

Our attention has been drawn to a report published by the Daily Independent newspaper on the 14th of September 2020, with the title: “Fraud Rocks NCDC COVID-19 Tests For Air Travellers”

This report is simply incorrect and based on information that is inconsistent with the truth. In addition, no attempt was made to contact the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) on this matter before the newspaper went to press. This article is an unfortunate misrepresentation of efforts by Government Ministries and Agencies, to enable safe travel in the context of a pandemic affecting every country in the world.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Oyo State government ordered the closure of schools in the state from March 20 until June 29. Only graduating pupils in Primary 6, Junior Secondary School 3 and Senior Secondary School 3 will resume. Higher institutions, day care centres and other classes in primary and secondary schools, apart from final classes, will remain closed. UPDATE: By the new arrangement, teachers are to resume to the schools on Monday June 29, 2020, while students in critical classes including Primary 6, JSS3 and SS3 will resume a week later on July 6, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020.

description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020. On 28th of March Governor Atiku Bagudu of Kebbi state also ordered that all schools including Islamiyya and Almajiri Schools should remain closed till further notice. UPDATE: Originally th epolicy for school closure was limited to 30 days but on 28th of March the governor of Kebbi state changed to an indefinite date. Also, religious schools have to close as well.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020. On 28th of March Governor Atiku Bagudu of Kebbi state also ordered that all schools including Islamiyya and Almajiri Schools should remain closed till further notice. UPDATE: Originally th epolicy for school closure was limited to 30 days but on 28th of March the governor of Kebbi state changed to an indefinite date. Also, religious schools have to close as well.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 14, Kwara State Ministry of Education and Human Capital Development under the leadership of Ahmed Fatimah Bisola, Commissioner, has designed a “mass media class” for Senior Secondary School students in the state to mitigate effect of the closure of schools due to the Coronavirus pandemic. By this programme, students preparing for WAEC and NECO examinations can sit back at home and watch or listen to lessons by the teachers on Television and Radio stations as scheduled.

description: Following the directive of President Muhammadu Buhari via a March 29th, 2020 pronouncement to the Minister of Humanitarian Affairs, Disaster Management and Social Development, to liaise with State governments to develop strategies on the continuation of the school feeding programme, the Federal Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs, Disaster Management and Social Development, will commence the Home-Grown School Feeding Programme, on May 14, 2020, in Abuja and subsequently, in Lagos and Ogun States, before the other States of the Federation. The target beneficiaries are defined as children in primary 1 to 3 in public schools participating in the programme.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On 18th March Northwest Zone Governors Forum in Nigeria have converged in Kaduna and resolved to close down schools in their states for 30 days. Present at the meeting are the governors of Katsina, Zamfara, Sokoto, Jigawa, Kebbi, Kaduna, and Niger States, while Kano deputy governor Nasiru Gawuna represented governor Umar Ganduje. The closure will take effect from Monday 23rd of March 2020. UPDATE: The original closure of schools by the governors of Northwestern States in Nigeria which was also effective in Kano State was set to last until April 22, 2020. The closure of schools has been extended indefinitely. On May 25, 2020, the Kano State Government said that there is no set date for the reopening of schools that has been closed since March 23, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On March 23, Cross River state government announced a school closure, directing that all educational institutions in the state, both public and private, must shut down March 24, 2020 until further notice.

UPDATE: On June 9, Cross River state government announced that a trial resumption of schools would begin on June 16. UPDATE: The original order directed all schools to close March 24 until further notice, a trial resumption of schools is to begin on June 16.

description:
Following the announcement of the Nigerian Government on June 29 2020 to consider the safe reopening of schools to allow students in graduating classes to resume in-person in preparation for examinations,
the education minister, on July 9th 2020, said with the latest decision it will no longer be possible for students to prepare for or participate in any exams, including the external one conducted by the West African Examination Council (WAEC) as the number of COVID-19 cases in the country topped 30,000.

description:
Lagos state government closes all public and private schools from 23rd March.
After closing schools since march, Lagos state government on the 29th of July asks HER SS3 and TEC3 to resume on 3rd of Aug, in order to prepare for their West African Senior Secondary Certificate Exams. UPDATE: The Lagos State government has previously directed that all primary, secondary and tertiary institutions should be closed due to the pandemic on the 23rd of May. However, on the July 29th the commissioner of education announced that all the SS3 and Technical Studies (TEC3) students in both day and boarding schools in the state are to resume on Monday, August 3, 2020, to help them prepare for the forthcoming West Africa Senior Secondary Certificate Examination (WASSCE).
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: Osun state, Nigeria reopens school on August 4 for exit students with following guidelines: Parents are expected to provide face masks/nose covers for their children or wards, while Principals and Proprietors of Schools are expected to ensure a tidy environment with desks arranged at least two meters apart. This social distancing  shall be ensured by Class Wardens. Also, The Ministry of Education shall provide buckets, soap, hand sanitizers, thermometer and also fumigate all schools. The Ministry of Health shall also provide Vitamin C tablets for students. NCDC or the Ministry of Health should be alerted in case of any sign of infection in any of the schools. Preschool, Primary schools and higher education institutions are still closed.

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
EDUCATIONAL
INSTITUTIONS (Daycare, Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary) 
Observe all mandatory non-pharmaceutical interventions;
Ensure that all staff and students above the age of 18 are fully
vaccinated;
The use of Face masks should be made mandatory for all adults;
School management to be responsible for enforcement and
ensure compliance; and
For schools with accommodation facilities, consider the use of
approved Ag-Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDT) as recommended
in the GUIDANCE FOR THE USE OF APPROVED COVID-19
Ag- RDTs IN NIGERIA (check NCDC website)

UPDATED: On October 26, Cross River state governor Ayade announced the relaxing of the curfew to restrict movement only between the hours of 4pm and 8am. UPDATE: The original curfew was a 24 hour curfew, it has been relaxed to only between the hours of 4pm and 8am daily.

type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week

description:
Authorities in Anambra have imposed an indefinite nightly curfew in parts of the state effective April 26 in response to an attack by unidentified gunmen which left nine people dead the same day. The curfew will run 19:00-06:00 and specifically affects the communities of Aguleri, Awkuzu, Igbariam, Nteje, Umueri, and Umunya. Security forces have reportedly been ordered to enforce the edict strictly.

description:
The policy pertains to a curfew for the state of Bayelsa, Nigeria, and takes effect from 16/05/2021. It targets all the civilians of the state of Bayelsa, Nigeria. UPDATE: The original policy was stated for a curfew from 7pm to 7am but has been relaxed nationwide by the national government of Nigeria to 10:00 PM – 4:00 AM daily, however, healthcare workers and journalists
are exempted from this curfew. Banks have resumed normal working hours, while government
offices will be open 9:00 AM – 2:00 PM, Monday to Friday.

The nationwide curfew imposed from 12 Midnight to 04:00 am has
been lifted.
No formal restrictions on movement within the country.
The advisory limiting Nigerians to essential travels only has been lifted.

facemask/facial coverings in public

description: COVID-19 has reached state of emergency in Ondo, says Akeredolu, Ondo State Governor Oluwarotimi Akeredolu has expressed worries over the rising spike in COVID-19 cases in the state, with 100 new cases within eight days.  Akeredolu, who noted that as of Monday last week, the state had 74 cases, said that 174 confirmed cases had spread across the three senatorial districts of the state. While addressing journalists during the weekly briefing on the pandemic in Akure, the governor attributed the increase to non-committal attitude of the people to fight it. He said there were 1,052 reported cases, 1,257 samples collected, 71 active cases on admission, 18 deaths while 47 persons had been discharged so far.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From March 20, Nigeria's interior Minister announced that authorities will suspend issuing visas on arrival to any travelers from the affected countries. The countries on the list include the US, China, the UK, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. The ban will be reviewed after four weeks and may be extended or expanded depending on the situation.

description:
Following reports that persons on non-essential duties have continued to traverse the boundaries of Enugu State “with the tacit support of some unscrupulous persons” despite the state government’s COVID-19 Containment Order (Executive Order No. 1 of 2020) in force, Governor Ifeanyi Ugwuanyi has on April 30, 2020, directed all the 17 Local Government Council Chairmen “to mobilize all Development Center Administrators, Councilors, Traditional Rulers and Presidents General of Communities as well as Neighborhood Watch Groups and Youth Leaders within their jurisdiction to man the borders of their local Government Council Areas that are contiguous with other States”.

 UPDATE: The original external border restriction policy closed all land and interstate borders within the state. This policy has been strengthened to ensure strict compliance.

description: In an address monitored in Benin City, Governor Godwin Obaseki, said with 11 confirmed cases as at Wednesday, April 8, evidence showed that the number of cases was likely to increase significantly in the next few weeks. Now is completed the first set of training for all health workers in Edo State who will man the screening and isolation centres.

description: On May 16th, 2020, Nigeria commenced Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) training specifically for younger male students, called Almajirai (also commonly spelled Almajiri), in Kano State. This training is for the purpose of reducing the risk of the spread of COVID-19 on the streets of the northern regions of Nigeria, and to move the boys to temporary medical centers before reuniting them with their families.

description: On June 1, Yahaya Bello, governor of Kogi said that contact tracing should be carried out house to house to identify those who might have made contact with the alleged Kogi COVID-19 index persons. description:
06 June 2020 | Abuja – 100 DAYS OF NIGERIA’S COVID-19 RESPONSE

On the 27th of February 2020, Nigeria confirmed its first case of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). One hundred days after, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) has reported 11,844 confirmed cases and 333 deaths. Additionally, 3,696 people have been treated and discharged successfully. The COVID-19 pandemic has affected over 100 countries across the world. Over 6 million people have been affected, and the number of deaths has exceeded 300,000 as at the 6th of June 2020.
type_sub_cat: A community’s epidemiological status
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On the 29th of February 2020, the Niger State Governor, Sani Bello, 
reintroduced monthly sanitation at emergency centers in Minna, Bida, Kontagora, Suleja and New Bussa. The Commissioner for Environment, Tanko Zakari, reiterated that the aim to re-introduction of environmental sanitation exercises in state was to reduce health challenges attributable to dirty environments, thus reduce pressure on the states healthcare centres. The Governor solicited the support of the people and the Local Government Chairmen to ensured that the desired objective was achieved.

The Commissioners for Health (Dr. Muhammad Makusidi) and Water Resources (Alh. Yusuf Suleiman) pledged their support in ensuring a healthy environment and treated pipe-borne water to people for effective hygiene and sanitation.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 10, Kwara State Governor AbdulRahman AbdulRazaq has announced that they refurbished the state’s oxygen plant, over nine years after it last functioned at usable capacity. The revamped facility bolsters Kwara’s capabilities to manage Coronavirus (COVID-19) patients who may require ventilators for a lifeline. The Governor also commended the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) for helping the state to recover looted funds which have become useful in the campaign against COVID-19. AbdulRazaq said the recovered funds strengthened Kwara’s ability to put in place necessary facilities, among other counter-COVID-19 efforts. The Governor said the government has turned around the Sobi Specialist Hospital which is now the COVID-19 response center of the state. The administration is now working on having an isolation centre in Offa after which another would be created in General Hospital Kaiama. They had bought five new ambulances (three on the ground and two are on the way) and a mobile x-ray machine. They have also 10 ventilators now and they expect to have 30 by the end of the month.
type_sub_cat: Ventilators
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Covid-19 task center have created three centres for isolating Covid-19 patients as follows: a) A 150-bed capacity hospital at Kwadon which has been fully renovated and furnished for the management of mild-to-moderate cases; b) A 12-bed capacity Intensive Care Unit (ICU) at the State Specialist Hospital, Gombe has been established and is fully equipped for the management of severe cases including mechanical ventilation and other intensive care needs; c) A 50-bed capacity fully equipped facility at Federal Teaching Hospital, Gombe; d) Additional isolation facilities are also being prepared at Funakaye and Kaltungo LGAs in order to ensure effective coverage of the state.

description: Following evolving evidence on the transmission of COVID-19, the World Health Organization (WHO) provided recommendations for the wearing of face masks by the general public. This is especially important where there is ongoing widespread transmission and physical distancing is difficult, such as in public transport, markets, and confined or crowded environments. In Nigeria, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 mandated the use of face masks or coverings in public spaces, on the 27th of April 2020. The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) published advisories on the use of face masks and guidance on making cloth masks.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 7, Kogi State Governor Yahaya Bello has announced full insurance for health workers involved in the fight against coronavirus spread in the state. He said in Lokoja when officials of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control led by Dr Noah Andrew visited him. The moves were aimed at boosting health workers’ confidence. NCDC delegation that the state Ministry of Health had deployed health workers in the 239 wards making up the state, as well as two officials who would sensitize residents to the dangers of the virus in each of the wards. They have set up three modern isolation/containment centres in the state with 130 bed spaces. Also provided emergency and toll-free numbers for the general public to call in and report suspected cases of Covid-19.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Materials
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),No special population targeted

description:
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) continues to lead the public health response to the COVID-19 outbreak in Nigeria. Following the review of recent restriction measures by the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19, NCDC has developed new guidelines for places of worship in Nigeria. This is to ensure safe gatherings and prevent exposures to COVID-19 infection in religious settings.

On the 2nd of June 2020, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 announced the relaxation of the previous ban placed on religious settings, allowing faith groups to meet while adhering to public health and social measures.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Nigerian Army sets up COVID-19 isolation centre in Ondo.  In its efforts to support the government at all levels in fighting against the spread of coronavirus disease, the Nigerian Army has set up an isolation centre at 32 Artillery Brigade, Owena Cantonment, Akure, in Ondo State.  It is aimed at Nigerian officers serving in the army as that two months ago, an army officer who recently returned from India to Ondo state tested positive for COVID-19.

description: On July 4, The Kwara State government has announced the receipt of N243m as financial donations from private individuals and corporate bodies between March 27th and July 4th. These expenses covered the purchase of military grade Toyota Land Cruiser Ambulances; automated ventilators and several other Intensive Care Unit (ICU) gadgets/equipment; production of hand sanitizers; and the cost of running the activities of the technical committee and its subcommittees, the statement reads. The expenses also covered the cost of the palliatives that were distributed during the lockdown; renovation of the Sobi Specialist Hospital and the Hajj Camp; mass production of face masks, purchase of surgical masks, digital thermometers, N95 and respirator-sperien 5311 and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Others are; medical supplies and consumables; security expenses; training; allowances for medical personnel and other supportive staff in charge of the pandemic; part-renovation of the Offa General Hospital as an isolation centre; and patients’ management, among others.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),No special population targeted

description: On Friday, July 24th, the Nigerian Government conducted training for 50 TB/HIV/ COVID-19 coordinators on basic Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) practices in Kano State. IPC practices include ensuring early triage, recognition, and source control at the point of entry to a facility, the implementation of hygienic precautions for all patients within facilities, the proper use and disposal of all PPE, and proper social distancing of patients as well as proper ventilation for all facilities housing known COVID-19 patients. Specific precautions vary depending on the type of facility (e.g. patient room, laboratory, waiting/holding room, etc.)
type_sub_cat: Unspecified Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
25 September 2020 | Abuja – NCDC Donates Treatment Centre to Federal Capital Territory for Management of Cases

On the 25th of September 2020, the Honourable Minister of Health, Dr Osagie Ehanire led the official handover ceremony of the Infectious Disease Care Centre built and equipped by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), to the management of the University of Abuja Teaching Hospital (UATH), Gwagwalada. This project was born out of the need for a treatment centre for serious infectious diseases in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) following the 2018 Lassa fever outbreak.

Party chairs killed in Nasarawa, Katsina
2 hours ago
How delayed preventive plans encouraged yellow fever, others, by FG, experts
1 hour ago
Oil, gas firms move for better environment via reduced methane emissions
2 hours ago

To cushion the effect of COVID-19 on residents of the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) has flagged off the distribution of palliatives and cash transfer to three Abuja Area Councils with the sum of $1.1million. The area councils are Abuja Municipal (AMAC), Bwari and Gwagwalada. 

The palliative include the donation of N14, 000 and 75,000kg of grains from the Federal Strategic Grain Reserve to 15,000 households in the FCT. To ease transfer of the fund, account was opened for beneficiaries in a commercial bank.

description: Following evolving evidence on the transmission of COVID-19, the World Health Organization (WHO) provided recommendations for the wearing of face masks by the general public. This is especially important where there is ongoing widespread transmission and physical distancing is difficult, such as in public transport, markets, and confined or crowded environments. In Nigeria, the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 mandated the use of face masks or coverings in public spaces, on the 27th of April 2020. The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) published advisories on the use of face masks and guidance on making cloth masks. UPDATE: As of May 11 2021, this policy is still in effect. There is a mandatory use of non-medical face masks in public spaces. ‘No mask, no entry. No mask, no service'. UPDATE: There was never an end date, but as of May 11 2021, there is still mandatory use of non-medical facemasks in public spaces. ‘No mask, no entry. No mask, no service'.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
21 September 2020 | Abuja – NCDC and NIMR launch COVID-19 Household Seroprevalence Surveys in Selected States of Nigeria

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) and Nigeria Institute for Medical Research (NIMR) and their partners are conducting household surveys in four states in Nigeria to better understand the burden of COVID-19 infection in Nigeria. These seroprevalence surveys, which will be carried out in Gombe, Enugu, Nasarawa and Lagos States will provide the best evidence yet, on the extent of COVID-19 infection in Nigeria.

description:
COVID-19: Ogun begins second round of community testing.  he Ogun State Government said it has commenced its community-based coronavirus testing across the 20 local government areas of the state in order to increase the test rate in the state and its environs.
The Commissioner for Health, Tomi Coker, made this known in a statement, explaining that the decision to domesticate Covid-19 testing in all the council areas of the state was on the national recommendation of community-based testing as a means of ascertaining the prevalence, improving early case detection and treatment of both symptomatic and asymptomatic cases.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
The Lagos State Government has confirmed some positive COVID-19 cases in a secondary boarding school on the mainland.

This was disclosed in a press release issued on Friday, November 6, 2020, by the Lagos State Commissioner for Health, Prof. Akin Abayomi.

Abayomi in his statement said that a member of the school’s staff was confirmed positive for COVID-19 infection on November 2, 2020, and contact tracing revealed that a student and four contacts of the affected staff also tested positive to COVID-19
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
November 6, 2020. An outbreak of an unidentified disease has claimed the lives of at least 57 people in the southeastern Nigerian state of Enugu, according to local media.
Nigeria/Alvaro1984 18

The communities of Ette and Umuopu have been affected since September.

Vincent Oshomi, a Disease Surveillance and Notification officer in the region, said before vomiting blood, the victims showed symptoms of diarrhea and convulsion.

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) says epidemiologists have been deployed. Initial samples from sick people returned negative for COVID-19, Lassa and yellow fever.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On January 26th 2021, the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria signed into law that "No person shall be allowed within the premises of a market, mall, supermarket, shop, restaurants, hotels, event centers, gardens, leisure parks, recreation centers, motor parks, fitness centre or any other similar establishment (hereinafter collectively referred to as "establishment") except: [they] wash [their] hands or cleaned the hands using hand sanitizer approved by the National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC)".

description:
On the 5th of April 2020, Ahmed Matane (Secretary to the State Government and the Chairman of the Niger Task Force on COVID-19) stated that intrastate movement of people and vehicles within the state remained banned, except those on essential services.

Matane also stated that Gov. Abubakar Bello invoked necessary constitutional powers to impose the curfew in state. These laws include: section 3 of the Restriction of movement of Person’s Law Cap 115, Laws of Niger state, 1989, section 40 of the Niger State Public Health Law, Cap. Section 2, 3 and 8 of the Quarantine Act Cap Q2 Laws of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, 1999.

description:
On the 5th of April 2020, Ahmed Matane (Secretary to the State Government and the Chairman of the Niger Task Force on COVID-19) stated that intra and inter-state movement of people and vehicles across the state remained banned, except those on essential services. The Chairman said that local Government Areas that share border with neighboring states have been directed to ensure effective monitoring of movements.

Matane also stated that Gov. Abubakar Bello had invoked necessary constitutional powers to impose the curfew in state. These laws include: section 3 of the Restriction of movement of Person’s Law Cap 115, Laws of Niger state, 1989, section 40 of the Niger State Public Health Law, Cap. description:
Nigeria will begin reopening its airports from July 8 following a three-month lull due to the coronavirus outbreak, the country's aviation minister said Wednesday. 

Flights will initially resume between the capital Abuja and Lagos. Airports in Kano, Port Harcourt, Owerri and Maiduguri will resume operations on July 11, and domestic flights at other airports will resume on July 15, Hadi Sirika said on Twitter.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Nigeria's Centre for Disease Control from September 2020 suggests that travellers should self-isolate. They should avoid situations where they would be mixed with other people or family members for a period of 14 days. Those who are self-isolating include all returning travelers to Nigeria, Anyone who has been in close contact with a confirmed case of Covid-19, Discharged Covid-19 patients for at least one week. Effective from the 5th of september, the Presidential task force has revised the quarantine protocol for all returning travelers to Nigeria. Non-Nigerians may be refused entry at a cost to the airlines, Nigerians may be given access with a mandatory 14 day quarantine under governmental facilities for supervision. On arrival to Nigeria Passengers shall go through screening, passengers will proceed on a 7 day self-isolation. Persons found negative after the 7 day self-isolation will be allowed to exit self-isolation, the international travel from Nigeria to other countries is country specific.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

All citizens in these areas are to stay in their homes. Travel to or from other states should be postponed. All businesses and offices within these locations should be fully closed during this period except for hospitals and all related medical establishments as well as organizations in health care related manufacturing and distribution. Commercial establishments such as; a. food processing, distribution and retail companies; b. petroleum distribution and retail entities, c. power generation, transmission and distribution companies; and d. private security companies are also exempted, however they will be restricted and monitored.

description: On April 10, Kwara State Government has announced total lockdown of the state. The new measure banned all vehicular movement, including private vehicles, all manners of shops and markets. Food sellers and operators of medicine stores are allowed to operate on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays between 10a.m. and 2p.m. All health workers remain exempted from this lockdown. Kwara Farmers who can identify themselves with any registered farming associations are allowed to go to their farms during the total lockdown the government has declared to prevent the spread of Corona Virus in the state. The Kwara State Technical Committee on COVID-19 also exempted journalists on duty from the lockdown in line with global best practices during such emergencies.  It is also to be noted that previous waivers to manufacturing firms are still valid on the condition that they maintain social distancing and scale down their operations. Petrol stations, banks, and hospitals are also exempted from the lockdown on the condition that all safety protocols are adhered to.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description:
The national government begins phase 2 of their lockdown, which will be in place from June 2nd 2020 to June 29th 2020. Phase 2 eases the lockdown and the following measures are in place: 
The nationwide curfew remains in place but the time has been changed to 10:00 P.M. – 4:00 A.M. daily. Healthcare workers and journalists are exempted from his curfew.  
·Banks may resume normal working hours. 
·Government offices will be open between 9:00 A.M. and 2:00 P.M. Monday – Friday.  
·The ban on interstate movement remains in effect except for agricultural produce, petroleum products, manufactured goods, and essential services.  
·All airports remain closed to domestic and international travel, except for emergency flights.
Face masks or coverings are mandatory in public settings and hand washing/sanitizing practices must continue to be followed.  
·Ban on gatherings of more than 20 people outside of a workplace. 
·Relaxation of restrictions on places of worship based on guidelines issued by the PTF and State governments.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Nasarawa state, Nigeria, will have a relaxed lockdown on Wednesdays and Saturdays between the hours of 10:00am to 2:00pm to enable the residents to purchase essential commodities in shops within their neighborhoods from April 16. From June 4 all markets are reopened and it will be a curfew between 10pm to 6pm instead of lockdown. description: On June 5, The Governor of Kogi State, Alhaji Yahaya Bello has lifted the absolute lockdown placed on Kabba/Bunu communities over the alleged COVID19 index cases in those communities. The governor’s pronouncement was coming barely three days into the contact tracing and testing of people in the communities. According to the governor the purpose of the lockdown in those communities have been achieved and need no further delayed for the initial 14 days declared. UPDATE: The original lockdown would last until June 15 in Kaba/Bunu but Kogi State Governor has lifted the lockdown on June 5 in Kaba/Bunu.

description:
The governor of Nigeria’s commercial capital Lagos said on Saturday churches and mosques would reopen next week as the authorities move to ease the lockdown over the coronavirus pandemic.

Read the latest updates in our dedicated coronavirus section.

“Places of worship in Lagos will now be opened from Friday, the 7th of August for our Muslim worshippers, and on Sunday, the 9th of August for our Christian worshippers,” Babajide Sanwo-Olu said in a statement.

description:
The national government begins phase 2 of their lockdown, which will be in place from June 2nd 2020 to June 29th 2020. Phase 2 eases the lockdown and the following measures are in place: 
The nationwide curfew remains in place but the time has been changed to 10:00 P.M. – 4:00 A.M. daily. Healthcare workers and journalists are exempted from his curfew.  
·Banks may resume normal working hours. 
·Government offices will be open between 9:00 A.M. and 2:00 P.M. Monday – Friday.  
·The ban on interstate movement remains in effect except for agricultural produce, petroleum products, manufactured goods, and essential services.  
·All airports remain closed to domestic and international travel, except for emergency flights.
Face masks or coverings are mandatory in public settings and hand washing/sanitizing practices must continue to be followed.  
·Ban on gatherings of more than 20 people outside of a workplace. 
·Relaxation of restrictions on places of worship based on guidelines issued by the PTF and State governments. 
UPDATE: Phase 2 of eased lockdown has ended, and phase 3 has started as of October 27, 2020. Phase 3 includes an emphasis on protective measures, opening of certain public spaces though bars and clubs remain closed. UPDATE: Phase 2 of the eased lockdown was extended to October 27, 2020 and has now ended and phase 3 of the eased lockdown has begun as of October 27, 2020. Phase 3 has an emphasis on protective measures, opening of certain public spaces though bars and clubs remain closed.

description: The Anambra State of Nigeria's House of Assembly passed a bill on April 16, 2020 to prevent the spread of Coronavirus and other dangerous infectious diseases in the state. The bill increases governmental power to punish those who disobey government directives dealing with infectious disease. These provisions include empowering the Chief Judge of the state to designate such number of Magistrate’s Courts or High Courts in any senatorial zone of the state as he may think appropriate for the summary and expeditious hearing and determination of all matters on violation of relevant provisions of the law.

description: The Anambra State Government announced on May 25, 2020 the creation of community COVID-19 teams for each of the state's wards, following the success of the COVID-19 task force at a state level. These smaller teams would be comprised of the Officer-in-Charge of Primary Healthcare Center, the Community Woman Leader, the Community Youth Leader, the Representative of the Ministry of Health and the Representative of the Civil Society. The teams would be headed by the Councilor of the Ward, but the Local Government Chairman and his Medical Team shall supervise the activities of the entire Team. This new structure is intended to help ramp up testing in local communities.

description: Nigeria's Anambra State Government announced on June 2, 2020 new protocol for the sampling and reporting of COVID-19 cases. According to the announcement, all members of the Nigerian Medical Association practicing in Anambra State were hereby expected to inform the Ministry of Health once they collect samples of suspected Covid-19 patients for testing. This is in order to ameliorate a prior issue of members collecting samples and sending them to the testing centers on their own. All Covid-19 efforts in Anambra State with regards to the collection of samples and the presentation of specimen to NCDC must be centralized going forward.

description: On April 28, The Edo State Governor, Godwin Obaseki has launched an online homeschooling platform, EDO-BEST@Home, which enables pupils learn from resources downloaded from an online database while at home. Obaseki said the platform is part of steps taken by the state government to ensure academic engagement by students, who ought to have resumed for a new term on April 27, but would have to remain at home as a result of the partial lockdown imposed to check the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The platform supported by State Universal Basic Education Board (SUBEB), MTN Nigeria also benefiting from a strong alliance between the government, the private sector, and the World Bank. The state is also developing interactive quizzes delivered to parents’ mobile phones to maximize the interaction between learners and teachers.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: on June 27th, 2020, The Rivers State Executive Council has approved Guidelines for Marraiges/Weddings in the state during the period of Covid 19.
type_text: The Rivers State Executive Council has approved Guidelines for Marraiges/Weddings in the state during the period of Covid 19.  Prospective Couples would need to get an approval/ apply to the Governor through the Commisioner for Social Welfare.  All Weddings/Marraiges have an attendance limit of 50 people.  The names, addresses and phone number of all attendees made available with the application (To enable quick contact tracing if the need arises).  Soap and running water has to be kept at the entrance to the venue in not less than three places while all attendees are to wear face masks and maintain social distancing of not less than 2 meters.  Church weddings are to be conducted between 9am and 12noon, while traditional weddings are to be conducted between 4pm and 7pm.  A representative of the Ministry would be present to observe the event.  A fine of N10,000,000 is to be paid by anyone that puts people at risk by breaking this regulation.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Lagos, Nigeria, 29 September 2020 – The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), in partnership with the Lagos State Government and the Federal Ministry of Humanitarian Affairs, Disaster Management and Social Development (FMHDS) has launched an Unconditional Cash Transfer project targeting the poor and vulnerable in Lagos state, largely funded by the European Union (EU). description:
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) joins the global movement to motivate all citizens to wear a face mask. World Mask Week (WMW) aims to reinforce the importance of wearing a face mask to reduce the spread of COVID-19. In the absence of a vaccine that can prevent infection, and as COVID-19 cases increase globally, citizens must depend on non-pharmaceutical measures, which include the use of face masks, hand washing, physical distancing and supportive management of confirmed cases to mitigate the impact of the disease.

World Mask Week, an initiative from a coalition of organisations including the Pandemic Action Network (PAN), World Health Organisation (WHO), Africa CDC and private companies working to mitigate the effects of COVID-19 globally, will run from August 7th -14th 2020.

description:
20th September 2020 | Abuja - PUBLIC HEALTH ADVISORY- NO EVIDENCE ON BENEFIT OF ‘AIR DOCTOR’ TAGS AGAINST COVID-19

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is aware of the wrong use of body worn labels or tags often marketed as ‘Air Doctor’ by members of the public. There is no scientific evidence that these tags can protect individuals from getting infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

NCDC’s advice is that anyone that chooses to wear these tags, should continue to adhere to the other non-pharmaceutical interventions, which we know reduces the risk of transmission of the virus.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
LAGOS, Oct 16 (Reuters) - A total of 181 students and staff at a private boarding school in the Nigerian capital Lagos have tested positive for coronavirus, state health authorities said on Friday.

Authorities said there had been a “minor but significant” outbreak among the 441 staff and students at the school in the suburb of Lekki and said most of the now-quarantined positive cases were asymptomatic.

description:
07 November 2020 | Abuja – Response to Suspected Yellow Fever Outbreak in Delta and Enugu States

The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) is currently supporting the Delta and Enugu State Governments, in response to suspected outbreak of yellow fever. This is following reports of a sudden spike in cases and deaths in some communities in both states.

On the 2nd and 3rd of November 2020, NCDC was notified by the State Ministries of Health of Delta and Enugu States respectively, of cases presenting with symptoms indicative of a viral haemorrhagic fever. Most cases presented with fever, headache, fatigue, jaundice vomiting (with or without blood) among others.

Specifically, “From midnight of Thursday, 26th March, 2020, all residents of Kaduna State are quarantined and must stay at home. No office, event centre, market, shop or business of any sort or place of worship is allowed to open; The only category of persons exempted are workers in essential services such as health workers, the fire service and security personnel. The markets will be now be open Tuesdays and Thursdays from May 4.

description: The state government of Ekiti in Nigeria announced that "all non-essential workers in public and private sectors are encouraged to work from home" starting on March 23. UPDATE: The original policy was that all non-essential workers in the private and public sectors are encouraged to work from home from Monday, March 23, 2020. The policy has ended as the Ekiti State Government announced that business activities are to resume for three days a week (Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays) between the hours of 07:00-16:00 starting on May 4, 2020.

description:
The Borno State Government, on May 13 2020, warned that all hotels and alcohol joints in the state remain closed.

The wearing of face masks in public will be mandatory on those days. On both days, only Yankaba Market, where perishable items are sold, and Yan Lemo Market, would be allowed to operate. Published 05/18/2020. Implemented 05/18/2021

description: The Ekiti State Government on April 21, 2020, banned food markets in Ado-Ekiti and Ikere-Ekiti with history of heavy population. The affected markets include Oja Oba, Bisi Market and Shasha market. UPDATE: The closure of food markets in Ado-Ekiti and Ikere-Ekiti including Oja Oba, Bisi Market and Shasha market was set to last throughout the period of the ongoing lockdown until April 27 2020. On April 27 2020, the Ekiti State Government announced that Oja Oba, Oja Bisi, Shasha and major LGA market days, remain closed. On May 18 2020 the Ekiti State Government decided to reopen the Oja Oba, Shasha and Bisi Markets.

description: On May 20, Cross River State governor Ayade announced (that beginning the same day) specifications for the State tax exemption law. All categories of people that qualify will be announced by the Governor from time to time. In this announcement he included: all hotels with less than 50 rooms, Okada riders, taxi drivers, airport taxi drivers, small saloon owners, small catering, "mama put" restaurants, those who sell basic things to earn a living, Keke-Napep, hawkers, market women, barbers.

description: The Ekiti State government has directed that starting from Monday, May 4th 2020 in Ekiti State, business activities will resume for only 3 days a week (Mondays, Wednesdays & Fridays) from the hours of 7 am – 4 pm only, to allow the self-employed earn some income to feed their families & not wait solely on govt for palliatives. UPDATE: The Ekiti State Government ordered business activities to resume for only 3 days a week (Mondays, Wednesdays & Fridays) from the hours of 7 am – 4 pm starting from May 4 2020. The policy has ended as the Ekiti State Government announced that with effect from June 1 2020 residents of Ekiti State now have opportunities to pursue their businesses Mondays through Friday from 6 am to 8 pm.

description: On the 3rd of September 2020, the Akwa Ibom state government has released nine-point Covid-19 guidelines for reopening hotels and tourism centers across the state. The guidelines would help ease the five-month lockdown period in the state. The guidelines included handwashing, provision of isolation rooms in hotels, physical social distancing, checking of body temperatures, fumigation of hotel premises with recommended chemicals, and training staff members in handling Covid-19 related issues.

description: The Katsina State Government of Nigeria announced on March 26th, 2020 that civil servants should observe that day as a work-free day as a measure to prevent the spread of Coronavirus. The Katsina Head of Civil Service said that the government would review the situation in the next two days before announcing the next line of action. Ultimately, the government decided to have civil servants return to work on April 6th, 2020 to begin providing skeletal services. UPDATE: Initially, the Katsina State Government directed civil servants to stay home indefinitely. However, they announced that on April 6, 2020, civil servants would return to work to begin providing skeletal services from the hours of 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for the next week.

UPDATE: The original stay at home order for non-essential civil servants was set to last until April 14, now only civil servants from grade level 10 are to return to work on April 14 while the rest are to stay home.

description: Kwara State Technical Committee on COVID-19 pandemic on May 14 asked the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Health, Ayinla Abubakar to proceed on indefinite suspension. The decision followed the mishandling of the evacuation of a man who locals said had locked himself in his vehicle for days and had become distressed following some personal life challenges. The state governor, Abdulrahman Abdulrazaq, approved the appointment of 10 new permanent secretaries (PS) to head various ministries, departments, and agencies of the government — barely two weeks after a crop of eight new PS were unveiled.

description: On July 24, Kwara State Government announced the cancellation of Eid-ul-adha congregational prayers across the state, citing the steep rise in the state’s Covid-19 cases and the danger of such a large gathering worsening the situation. The Government also announced a ban on vigils in churches and mosques while restating the ban on concert, clubbing, beer parlour, and bar in hotels. Kayode Alabi, Deputy Governor and Chairman of the Kwara State Technical Committee on COVID-19, told a news briefing in Ilorin, the capital city, that the decision to cancel the Eid prayers was a painful but necessary one to save lives.

description: Nigeria's Centre for Disease Control released a statement on the 30th of November 2020, introducing stricter measures for travel bans. This included cross-country and cross-city travel. It is an awareness campaign aimed at reducing the number of infections in the upcoming Christmas and New Year festives. Non-essential travel locally and internationally have been discouraged. Travel from countries that have recorded a higher rate of infections to Nigeria have also been discouraged. Local travels from urban or semi-urban areas to rural areas has been discouraged as rural areas have weak infrastructure to deal with any viral surges. Upon arrival to Nigeria travellers are encouraged to quarantine for seven days. Social gatherings are to be virtually conducted and the holidays are to involve only closer family members. A social distancing of 2 meters is recommended. Sanitizers and washing hands is also recommended.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Nigeria is enforcing a cross-country and cross-city travel ban for the christmas and new year festives. Travellers from countries that recorded a higher rate of infections to Nigeria are not encouraged. Passengers are tested through a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in their country of exit 120 hours before boarding. Furthermore, upon arrival in Nigeria, travellers should self-quarantine for seven days. Non-essential local and international travels are discouraged. Social and religious gatherings are only allowed through video calls. Family gatherings should ensure sanitization, 2 meter social distancing, washing of hands, avoid people showing symptoms. People above the age of 60 should avoid having visitors and friends coming over. Urban and semi-urban travel to rural areas is discouraged due to the weak infrastructure from such areas.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Nigeria's national government has banned social gatherings of more than 50 people. Any gathering of more than 50 people must be outside. UPDATE: the restrictions on mass gatherings outside the workplace remains to be no more than 50 persons. UPDATE: Announced May 11 2021, this restriction of no more than 50 people gathering is to be maintained.

description:
RELIGIOUS CENTRES (Churches/Mosques, etc.)
Limitation on the number of persons and 50% limit on persons
attending religious gatherings is lifted;
Face masks must continue to be used in all indoor religious
gathering; and
Congregants should take personal responsibility and take
appropriate personal safety protection measures.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
GATHERINGS like Weddings, Parties, and Meetings in Nigeria 
Limitation on the number of persons attending informal and
formal festivity events including weddings, conferences,
congresses, office parties, seminars, end-of-year events
has been lifted;
Ban on Concerts, carnivals, and street parties is hereby
lifted
For all Indoor events, it is Mandatory to continue wearing of
facemasks; and
All attendees are advised to take appropriate personal
protection includes safe physical distancing and the use of hand
sanitizers
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
ALL POLITICAL ACTIVITIES 
 All political activities in Nigeria involving large gatherings are to
strictly adhere to COVID-19 Guidelines issued by INEC;
Organizers to ensure the use of face masks (mandatory for
indoor meetings, while recommended for outdoor);
Mandatory Temperature checks and use of sanitizers at
events;
Political parties to be responsible for compliance with safety
measures; and
Voting procedures must comply with the stipulated
COVID-19 safety protocol by INEC.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 23, 2020, Governor Yahaya Bello of Kogi State gave a directive for all commercial motorists and cyclists that tricycle (Keke) operators may carry only one (1) passenger at a time and must provide hand sanitizers for use by their passengers. Also, regular 4-wheeled taxis may carry only three (3) passengers at a time (1 in front and 2 behind) and must provide hand sanitizers for use by their passengers. Furthermore, buses may carry only two (2) passengers per row of seats, subject to a maximum of 10 passengers per trip for any type of bus. Relevant officials are empowered to stop and enforce compliance, any defaulters will be arrested.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of buses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On the 31 March 2020, the governor of the Nigerian state of Akwa Ibom announced social distancing measures "To control the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and and prevent the spread of the disease, the movement of persons and vehicles within the State are hereby restricted as follows-
(a) commercial tricycles shall carry not more than two passengers only;
(b) Mini buses shall carry not more than one passenger per row; and
(c) a private vehicle shall carry not more than two persons at the back seat and one on the front Seat."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

The Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps, (NSCDC), Yobe State Command, has began the enforcement of social distancing policy by tricycle riders as directed by the state prevention committee on COVID-19.

description: Residents of Kwara State must use face mask in public places, keep physical distancing or stay indoors beginning from Friday July 24th, the government announced on July 20, with the State Technical Committee's protective applications on COVID-19, nobody would be allowed into any public building, markets, malls, transport, banks, and so on without their proper use of the face masks as a safety measure to lessen the transmission of the virus.

description: The Ogun State Government will begin enforcing the wearing of face masks in Ogun state from May 1, 2020. UPDATE: The Ogun State Government earlier enforced the wearing of face masks in Ogun state from May 1, 2020, with defaulters facing arrest and quarantine for 14 days. The Ogun State Government announced on 30 July 2020 that defaulters of the mandatory use of the face mask are punishable by up to six months imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Unspecified Mask Wearing Policy
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: By July 31st, 2020, the government would commence strict enforcement of the Kwara State Infectious Diseases Regulations 2020. Thenceforth, anyone seen outside without proper use of the face mask will be arrested, prosecuted in a mobile court, and taken to any of our quarantine centres. Their samples will then be taken and they will be held until their status is known. We want to emphasise that shop owners or business managers, drivers of commercial or private vehicles who allow persons without face masks into their shops or vehicles would be arrested alongside offending passengers and be taken to quarantine centres, have their samples taken and be held until their result is out.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation

description: On the 3rd of September 2020, the Akwa Ibom state government has released nine-point Covid-19 guidelines for reopening hotels and tourism centers across the state. The guidelines would help ease the five-month lockdown period in the state. The guidelines included handwashing, provision of isolation rooms in hotels, physical social distancing, checking of body temperatures, fumigation of hotel premises with recommended chemicals, and training staff members in handling Covid-19 related issues.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
HOSPITALITY AND ENTERTAINMENT FACILITIES
The limitation on the number of persons gathering in open spaces is
lifted, this applies to sports (stadium and arena), open
congregation and rallies;
All bars, nightclubs, pubs, and event centres are allowed to
open at 50% capacity; and
Capacity limitation on hotels, restaurants, and gyms has been lifted.
All hospitality and entertainment facilities to ensure the use of face
masks as well as safety precautions in their premises.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
EDUCATIONAL
INSTITUTIONS (Daycare, Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary) 
Observe all mandatory non-pharmaceutical interventions;
Ensure that all staff and students above the age of 18 are fully
vaccinated;
The use of Face masks should be made mandatory for all adults;
School management to be responsible for enforcement and
ensure compliance; and
For schools with accommodation facilities, consider the use of
approved Ag-Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDT) as recommended
in the GUIDANCE FOR THE USE OF APPROVED COVID-19
Ag- RDTs IN NIGERIA (check NCDC website)
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
COMMUNAL COMMERCIAL SPACES (Markets/Stores). The Nigerian government released the following guidelines:
Spot checks of commercial premises to be conducted
regularly;
Observe all mandatory non-pharmaceutical interventions; and
Facility owners/managers and store owners to ensure that
physical distancing is observed, provision of hand sanitizers
and handwashing facilities, ensure the mandatory use of face
masks and maintain environmental hygiene

description:
Limitation on number of staff reporting to work has been removed;
Normal work by ALL staff should resume in all offices, however it 
is advisable to continue measures that will reduce congestion in 
office spaces such as virtual meetings, working from home or onand-off days; and
Permanent Secretaries and Chief Executives are to ensure that 
all staff are fully vaccinated and the use of face masks and safety 
protocols are monitored within the office premises.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
